text: Hello - I'm wondering if there are any UX writers in this community who can point me to some courses for beginners, please?

elements.text: Hello - I'm wondering if there are any UX writers in this community who can point me to some courses for beginners, please?

text: What about offering to guest post on other fintech blogs for free to establish yourself as an authority in the space? That could help

elements.text: What about offering to guest post on other fintech blogs for free to establish yourself as an authority in the space? That could help

text: Hey folks, what do y'all do when you feel burnt out?

elements.text: Hey folks, what do y'all do when you feel burnt out?

text: Honestly, usually succumb to it lol. Lately, though I've been doing a lot of journaling to get my feelings out of my head. Surrounding myself with other creative people also helps. Going to online meetups with people doing what I do has been helpful in getting me to think outside the box and think about my problems in a new way. Also, talking with your manager and letting them know that you are feeling that way. Maybe there is a way to identify  two or three things that someone else on your team can manager for a few weeks so you can focus on you. Also time off so you can do some intentional thinking to get to the root of what's bothering you.

text:
Hey <@U035WGHQG3B>, I'm currently working at a venture-backed startup and I'd say those are where the good opportunities are to either a) be the first product and/or content marketer or b) be the first marketing hire. You should get paid well for this work and be able to grow with the company. When I was job hunting, I was looking for Series A or B companies, ideally PLG. I've worked at a top-down, sales-driven org before and I enjoyed it, but I think you can do some cool work as a marketer pre-sales team.

<@U03190ABB53>'s insights about content marketing not being the #1 hire is an interesting take and one I generally agree with, the only caveat being that content takes time to rank and show results, so you ideally want to be planting those seeds early.

The role I'm in now is kind of a hybrid of product and content marketing — I'm responsible for positioning, messaging, competitive research, launches, the website, and contributing to initiatives around onboarding, pricing, and customer research. But I'm also starting up the content marketing program (with a small team of freelancers!) because I have experience with that and we need to be focusing on top-of-funnel. I don't touch paid ads (except to have a sense of what we're doing); we're also in the process of hiring a Growth Lead.

For more great insights on this, I'm going to point to another MKT1 article about the fuel and the engine — such a good metaphor for how content/product/growth marketing work together: <https://mkt1.substack.com/p/fuel-engine?s=r>

attachments.fallback: Building an efficient marketing machine: the fuel & the engine
attachments.text: A simple framework for getting the mix of marketing activities correct, the right set of people on your marketing team, and high impact work out the door.
attachments.title: Building an efficient marketing machine: the fuel & the engine

text:
I suggest you step back and consider what's necessary in your life vs. what you can stop doing (or do less of) that drains you — not just work.

If you can afford to take a break and decompress, do that. But take a hard look holistically at how sustainable work and life are, the way you've been approaching them. If they're not, take steps to make sure that you're not just going to resume that after a break.

Often, people load themselves up with stuff, obligations or otherwise. Being able to say no is important. And no is a complete answer, one that doesn't require justification.

Also consider what helps energize or builds you up and how you can do more of that.

Bigger picture, we all have limited amounts of energy and focus. It's better to build things into your life that help you avoid burnout in the first place, rather than having to recover from it.

Personally, I say no a lot and don't feel any guilt about it. Why: Self-care is important. That's why they tell us to put our own oxygen masks on first.

Often, people load themselves up with stuff, obligations or otherwise. Being able to say no is important. And no is a complete answer, one that doesn't require justification.

Also consider what helps energize or builds you up and how you can do more of that.

Bigger picture, we all have limited amounts of energy and focus. It's better to build things into your life that help you avoid burnout in the first place, rather than having to recover from it.
